full mony haly poffeit scho pote doun
and wrot the pepill grit co[n]fusioun
Syne silly nabot for his wyneȝard scho slew
ȝit dra[n]k the doggis hir blude & banis gnew
Ffinis [etc]
Author unknown

head.title: Thot all þe wod vnder the hevin þat growis

lg.l: Thot all þe wod vnder the hevin þat growis
war crafty pe[n]nis convenie[n]t to wryte
and all the sie vndir the lift that flowis
war changeit in ynk and þat wer Infynyt
and þe erd maist plesand paper quhyt
all the men wer wryttaris þat evir tuik lyfe
Cowld not wryt the fals dissaitfull dispyt
and wicketnes co[n]tenit in a wyfe
[etc] ane vþir
Author unknown

head.title: Gif all the erth war perchmene scribable

lg.l: Gif all the erth war perchmene scribable
maid to þe hand and all man[er] of wud
wer hewit, and proportionat pe[n]nis able
all watter ynk In dame or in flude
and every ma[n] a p[er]fyt scryb and guid
The cursitnes and disset of wemen
cowld not be schawin be the mene of pen
[etc] q chaucer

head.title: The diuill Is not to daly stryf

lg.l: The diuill Is not to daly stryf
Comparesone to a wicket wyfe
a woma[n]is malice Is so fell
Exceiddis all the devillis in hell
Thair wordis thair workis and thair Ill tungis
hes cawsit full mony brokin rungis
[etc]
Author unknown

head.title: This work quha sa sall sie or reid

lg.l: This work quha sa sall sie or reid
of ony Inco[n]gruitie do me not Impeche
ordourly behuvis me first to proceid
In deductioun þairof in man[er] of a leche
his patie[n]tis seiknes, awchtis first to seiche
the qlk knawin medecyne he sowld apply
and schortly as be can schappin a remedy
Richt so by counsale willing the to exhort
o ȝung ma[n] prosprus quhilk dois abound
In thy flowris of lust belongith on this sort
me first to co[n]sidder quhat is rut & ground
of thy mischeif quhilk is planely found
woma[n] fersid wt frawid and dissait
To thy confusioun a most allectiue bait
Ffle the myswoma[n] leist scho the dissaif
This sayis salamon quhilk taucht was fully
The falsheid of woma[n] In his dayis to co[n]saif
The lippis of a stru[m]pet bene sueitar tha[n] huny
Hir throt he sayis sowplid wt oyll of flattry
Howbeit þe end and effect of all
Is bittirrer tha[n] ony wormewid or gall
Ffle the myswoma[n] luving thy lyfe
ware the strangeris bland eloquens
Strange I call hir þat is not thy wyfe
Off hir bewty haif no co[n]cupiscens
Hir countenance pretending (ignorans, struck through) benivolens
Bewar hir signys and ay so amiable
Hold it for serme thay bene dissavable
Lo ane example quhat woma[n] be
In thair signys and countena[n]s schortly
I will schaw the fow luvaris thre
Lovit on woma[n] ryt Inteirly
Eche (of, struck through) of thame knew vþiris maledy
Quhairfoir,, wes all þair daly lawbour
Quho culd approche most in hir favour
At sindre sessonis as fortoun requyrith
Seueraly thay come to se hir weilfair
But onis it appinit þat luve thame so fyrith
To se thair lady they all wald not spair
off vþiris cu[m]ing non of thame wes wair
Till all thay met Quhair as thay in place
off thair lady saw the desyrit face
To supper sett full smally thay eit
Ffull sobir and demure in contenance
Ffor thair tareid non of thame for ony meit
Bot on his lady to gife attendance
and in secreit wayse to gife signyfia[n]s
off lufe to haif Quhiche persaving sche
Ffetly executit thus hir propirtie
In dew sessone as scho all wayis espyid
every thing to execut co[n]veniently
Hir on luver first freyndly scho Eyid
The secound scho offerit þe cup courtesly
The thrid scho gaif takin secreitly
Vndirneth þe burde scho tred on his fute
Thruch his entrellis taklid the hart rute
By ȝour leif mycht I heir ask a questioun
Off ȝow my maisteris þat sew luvis trace
To ȝow lykly belongith the solutioun
Quchich of theis thre stoid now in grace
Cleirly to anser ȝe wald ask long space
The matir is dowtfull and opinable
To acertane ȝow I will my self vnable
Off þe foirsaid thre my self wes on
no ma[n] can ansueir it bettir tha[n] I
hertly of ws luvit wes thair non
Bot wattis pak we bur all by and by
Quhilk at last I my self can espy
and as I thot tyme Tha[n] I left the dance
O thotfull hairt grit is thy grevance
Quhairfoir the wysema[n] dois the adwyse
In quhois wordis can be fund no lesing
wt þe stranger to sit in no wayiss
Quhilk is not thy wyfe fall not in clepping
wt hir Bot be war eik of hir kissing
Keip wt hir at wyn no alteratioun
Lest that thyn hart fall by inclinatioun
Ffinis q chauseir

head.title: Bruthir be wyiss I reid ȝow now

lg.l: Bruthir be wyiss I reid ȝow now
wt ladeis gif it happynis ȝow
That welth no way ȝour wit mak blind
obey and for þe bettir bow
Remembir quhatt ma cu[m] behind
Thot ȝe be flowand in the rege
off fresche ȝowtheid and grene curage
and lycht as ony leif on lynd
and he extold in venus stege
Remembir quhat ma cu[m] behind
Suppoiss þat lufe be naturall
and in ȝowtheid most principall
Ryn not our far in to þe wind
at thy fute thot thow haif the ball
Reme[m]bir quhat ma cu[m] behind
Thot thow be sterk as herculess
Sampsone hector or achilless
Be forss thot thow may lowss and bynd
pentagora to preif in press
Remember [etc]
Ane vþir thing I do þe say
Preif nevir thy pith so far in play
That thow forthink þat thow come ind
and mvrn quhen thow no mendis may
Remembir [etc]
Thot thow be wyiss as salamone
or fair of feir as absolone
or riche as cryses out of kynd
or princis peir Ipomedone
Reme[m]bir [etc]
Gif thow be wyiss so is thair mo
gif thow be stark þair is also
Gife thow be gude Gud sall thow fynd
Gif thow be ill Thow fyndis thy fo
Remember [etc]
Thus sall thow stand in no degre
Sover ferout p[er]plexitie
Thot thow be nevir so noble of kynd
nor gre so grit of dignitie
Reme[m]bir [etc]
In all thy doingis haif gud skill
Continew in gude reforme þe Ill
do so þat dolour ma be dynd
Thuss may thow think gif þat thow will
Off gud and ill quhat cu[m]is behind
q Sr Iohine moffett

head.title: My luve was fals and full of flattry

lg.l: My luve was fals and full of flattry
wt cullerit lesingis full of dowbilness
Quhen þat scho spak hir toung was wonder sle
wt fals sembla[n]ce and fenȝeit humylness
and inconsta[n]ce pay[n]tit wt steidfastness
hir frane was cwverit wt ane piteous face
quhilk was þe causs þat oft I cryd allace
Scho luvit ane vdir bettir tha[n] scho luvit me
betuix þame twa thay draif me to grit skorne
Ffor it that I tald hir in priuitie
Scho tald it to hir luve vpoun þe morne
and sa betuix þame twa I gat þe horne
ȝit I cowld not p[er]saif thair fals co[n]sait
becauss thrut birna[n]d lust I was growin blait
The skorne þat I gatt micht bene maid ane farss
quhilk excedit þe skorne of absolone
quhen þe hett culter wes schott in his herss
be clerk nicolus and his luve allesone
As canterberry tailis makis mentioun
ȝit I suspekkit not bot scho wes trew
Bot I wes all begylit quhilk sair I rew
ȝung pirance the sone of erle dragabald
was dirlit wt lufe of fair meridiane
Scho promest him hir luve evin as he wald
and in ane secreit place gart him remane
Blawand ane kandill be art magicane
in frost and snaw quhill daylicht on þe morne
Bot my fillok did me far grittar skorne
Virgill quhilk (pr, struck through) was prude[n]t graif and saige
wass lichtleit be his luve wtout remeid
and for dispyt scho hang him in ane caige
and arristotill quhilk diu[er]ss doctrynis maid
his lady patt ane brydill in his heid
bot all thay skornis can not co[m]parit be
Till half the schame that my luve gart me dre
Siclyk scho wald be grit subtilitie
Ressaif fra me luve drwreiss belt and ring
and tha[n] wt thay same giftis offir wald sche
hir paramor and lait him wa[n]t no thing
vpoun the morne the same ringis he wald bring
and weir þame for dispyt befoir my face
To gar me ken he was mair in hir grace
God wait quhat wo had troyelus in deid
quhe[n] he beheld the belt þe broch and ring
hingand vpoun þe speir of diomeid
quhilk troyellus gaif to cresseid in luve taikni[n]g
on þat same sort (my, struck through) scho did to me maling
ffor tha giftis þat I gafe till hir all hour
wt þame scho did posses hir paramour
Bot quhan scho was in to necessitie
Than flattir me scho wald wt woirdis fair
ane fenȝeit teir scho wald thrist fra hir E
Lyk as for luve of me scho wald forfair
hir fenȝeit wo did sop my hart (frome, struck through) wt cair
tha[n] pety gart me gra[n]t till hir desyre
Becauss the luve brunt me lyk þe bald fyre
So day be day scho plaid wt me buk hud
wt mony skornis and mokkis behind my bak
hir subtill wylis gart me spend all my gud
quhill þat my clayis grew threidbair on by back
my vane p[er]sut gart me vin schame & lak
Quhill fra sic foly my hart dois now refrane
The devill ressaue me and I doid agane
Ffinis q weddirburne

head.title: Thir ladyis fair, That makis repair

lg.l: Thir ladyis fair, That makis repair,
and in the court ar kend
Thre dayis thair, Thay will do mair,
ane mater for till end,
Than thair gud men, will do in ten
for ony craft thay can
So weill thay ken, Quhat tyme and quhen
Thair menes thay sowld mak than
With littill noy, Thay can convoy
ane mater fynaly
richt myld & moy, and keip it coy
on evyns quyetly
Thay do no miss bot gif thay kiss
and keipis collatioun
Quhat rek of this, thair mater Is
Brocht to conclusioun
Wit ȝe weill, thay haif grit feill,
ane mater to solist
Trest as the steill, Syne nevir a deill,
quhen thay cum hame ar mist
Thir lairdis ar, me think richt far,
Sic ladeis behaldin to
That sa weill dar, Go to þe bar,
quhen thair Is ocht ado
Thairfoir I reid gif ȝe haif pleid
or mater in to pley
To mak remeid, send in ȝor steid,
ȝour ladeis grathit vpgay
Thay ca[n] defend, evin to þe end
ane mater furth express
Suppois thay spend It is vnkend
thair geir Is nocht the les
In quyet place, Thocht thay haif space,
wtin less nor twa howris
Thay can p[er]caice, purchess sum grace,
at the co[m]positouris
Thair compositioun, (s, struck through) wt full remissioun
Thair fynaly Is endit
wt expeditioun, and full conditioun
Thair seilis ar to pendit
Alhaill almoist, thay mak the coist,
with sobir recompens
richt littill loist, Thay get Indoist
alhaill thair evidens
Sic ladyis wyiss, Thay ar to pryis
to say the veretie
Swa can devyiss, and not suppryiss
thame, nor thair honestie
Ffinis q dumbar

head.title: The vse of court richt weill I knaw

lg.l: The vse of court richt weill I knaw
that ladeis ar solisteris of the law
at hame remanis the silly lairdis
and sendis thair wyvis behind the ȝerdis
weill stuffit with mony and rewairdis
To forder thair Eirandis fra nicht faw
In cloikis thay cum full quyet cled
and rownis to haif thair mater sped
Thay gif no buddis,
bot on thair luddis
thay get grit skuddis
lg.note: (Squiggly lines beside last three lines, [In nakit bed] beside line)

lg.l: Bot neuirtheles the laird mon fyne
for all (ane, struck through) hir menis ane tun of wyne
his wyfe cu[m]is hame baith wyd & vsit
Bot ȝit mon hald hir excusit
and fynaly the folkis þat duisit
lg.note: (Squiggly line beside last three lines, [denyis & lachis thame (^ with a dot above, [bayt to sl] struck through, ^ with a dot above and [to hething syne] below)] beside line)

lg.l: The laird mvrnis quhe[n] he ma not mendit
his wyfe Iaippit his silver spendit
and all hir labor turnit in vane
Bot ay the leddy sayis full plane
that scho mon to þe court agane
lg.note: (Squiggly line beside last three lines, [or ellis þe ply will not be e[n]dit] beside line)

lg.l: Hir buclar bord and (all, struck through) backwart borne
and all hir cauiss Is quyt forlorne
vp gettis hir wame
scho thinkis no schame
Ffor to bring hame
lg.note: (Squiggly line beside last three lines, [the laird a horne] beside line)

lg.l: Ffinis
Author unknown

head.title: The beistly lust the furius appetyt

lg.l: The beistly lust the furius appetyt
The haisty wo The verry grit defame
the blind discretioun the hatrent & dispyte
of wemen kynd that dreidis for no schame
That settis at nocht god nor ma[n]is blame
Thair lustis so hes nvreist thame but dreid
That all thair trest is thair god cupeid
The lustyest lady that natur can devyiss
Thot scho haif mony semely servitour
ȝit sall ȝe se hir suddanly Inclyne
to tak ane crukit crippill criateur
quhilk formit is ane owill be nateur
Sic is thair werd thairfoir quha sowld thame wyte
thair beistly lust & furius appetyte
And sen thir clerkis awld wret in to thair stylis
to ȝungar folk and þair successioun
for to eschew þe malice and the wylis
of wemen quhilk ar our oppressioun
Thir folkis wyiss of gud discretioun
hes teichit ws quhat skaithis and offens
that weme[n] dois be cullourit eloquens
And possible war in till ane cumly corss
wyiss salamons wit and his hie (ff or ss, struck through) sapience
arristotillis clergy Sampsonis strenth and forss
hectoris proves and achillis excellence
ȝit weme[n] sowld with wylie Influence
Cawiss all thir vertewis to be of non availl
with thair sle serpent wrinkis and fals taill
So dengerus, deir, dissavable ffull of disdane
So fenȝeit fals and with so littill feir
and quhair thay go thay beir the slaik stane
Go follow thame quha list vnlawty leir
Secreit invy and of dispyt the speir
wt weme[n] evill, It gois all quyt for evir
Quhilk sowld ws lerne ffra subteill huris dissevir
Ffinis [etc]
Author unknown

head.title: Devyce proves and eik humilitie

lg.l: Devyce proves and eik humilitie
that madyns had in everilk wyiss
Tra[n]sformit Is in serpentis crewaltie
fra thay in warld be weddit Trewth so tryiss
no ma[n]is wit to wounder ma suffyiss
Quhair ar becum thir madynis myld as mvde
of thir wyvis ar non now fundin gude
O madinheid of vertew nobillest
flurrissing in Ioy and p[er]fyte lawliness
o wyfheid wareit all vþiris wickettest
The moder of vice and hairtis hie distress
distroyaris of realmis and cuntreis as I gess
That all this warld hes brocht to confusioun
Begu[n]nyn was thruche thy p[er]swasioun
Exampillis ar how thyne Iniquitie
ouircu[m]in hes wisdome and strenth of hand
by salamone the first may provit be
wysest but weir In warld þat evir was levand
his grit wisdome micht not aganis the stand
Thow gart him ar in his lattir eild
declyne fra god and to þi ma[n]dme[n]ts ȝeild
Sampsone the ferss Strangest that evir was borne
of ma[n]ly (line) throw the distroyit was
Boith his ene blindit and eik forlorne
dauid that slew the gyand golias
and mony mo quhilk heir over pass
now to reherss for laik of tyme and wit
and labour grit quhilk will me nocht p[er]mit
Thow diuillis member Thow cursid homecyd
Thow tegir tene fulfillit of birnyng fyre
Thow vnsteidfast gevin ay to lust & pryd
Thow cokkatrice That with sicht of thyne yre
Effrayit hes full mony gudly syir
quhilk eftirwart in warld ha no plesance
grit god I pray the tak on thame vengance
Grit was the lust that thow had for to fang
the fruct vetite throw þi ill counsaling
Thow gart mankynd consent to do þat wrang
displeiss his god and brek his hie bidding
as haly writ beiris suthfast witnessing
Thairfoir thow frome the Ioy of paradyce
and thy ofspring was baneist for þat vyce
Bot than in madinheid was our first remeid
and frome the hevin our haly fader sent
The second p[er]sone syne in a godheid
To tak mankynd tha[n] of the virgin gent
Cleir of corss and clenar of Intent
quhilk buir the barne that coverit ws frome cair
scho beand virgin clenar tha[n] scho war
Ffinis q chawseir

head.title: O wicket wemen wilfull and variable

lg.l: O wicket wemen wilfull and variable
richt fals, feckle, fell, and frivolus
dowgit dispytfull, dour and dissavable
vnkynd crewall curst and covettus
ouirlicht of laitis vnleill and licherus
Turnit fra trewth and taiclit wt treichery
vnferme of faith fulfillit of fellony
O stowt stif standfra, and vnstable
vnmeik but mesur and malitius
angry, awstern, and till all evillis able
skornand, skaithfull, skald and most sklandrus
gredy, not gude, Grym, gray, and vngratius
(Noy, struck through) Noyus but neid and full of Iniquitie
vngentill Iugeit and full of Iolesie
Als terne as tygir of tung vntollerable
o thow violent virago vennemouss
blastera[n]d bald brym and abhominable
ourp[er]te reprevivable peirles and p[er]rellous
evill cristiane vnknawin, crafty and cawtelus
vnchest evill chosin, and all but cheretie
mellit with misdeid and all me[n]sworne ar ȝe
Ffinis q chauceir

head.title: Aganis mariage of evill wyvis

lg.l: Thankit be god and his appostillis twelf
I haif bene so weill fortunat in my lyfe
In to this warld in p(e, struck through)lesance be my self
To leif at eiss but sorrow of ane wyfe
No woundir thocht thair husbandis hairtis ryfe
for all the day he neidis no ill to borrow
disseiss, Chyding so haldis scho fast the knyfe
meit at his cheik ay forgit scherp with sorrow
Ffor be scho riche ony thing at eiss
tha[n] will scho say that scho and throw hir kin
(so fane scho wald hald him in to diseiss)
he wy[n]nis richt nocht Bot scho hes brocht it in
Than Is scho blyith quhe[n] he is in his skin
(bod, struck through) bowdin for baill, Lyik to a beist wald birst
Now is it nocht a foly to begin
To cheiss a lyif of all the warld the werst
And bring he in ane hundreth pund of guid
Scho and hir ȝung wenchis two or thre
Ane stane of woll thay mak with coistis ruid
and god wait how sorfett thay all wilbe
ffals churle q scho my quheill vphaldis the
cherryis my weme[n] and pay thame weill thair hyre
Than du[m]my standis with teir in to his Ee
wald scho and quheill war all in till a fyre
I can not tell the torment and the pyne
of thame that puttis thair nek this ȝok to draw
Ffull oft he feilis the brod and dar not quhryne
with anger smart than gan his hairt ouirthraw
Lyk to ane quhelp to cowche will beir him law
Than Is he baith hir servand and hir knaif
Now is it not a wicket seid to saw
of quhilk no grace nor fruct a ma[n] sall haif
Quhen I was ȝung I luvit p[ar]ramouris
ane lusty maid fulfillit of all plesance
and luve me sett sa far in aventour
all maist fra grace and gudly govirna[n]ce
Bot god provydit bettir for my chance
Quhairfoir ȝe ladyis be not with me wreth
for sickerly thair is no differance
Betuix the gallowis and the spowsing claith
Off weddit men as now I say na mair
I leif in eiss and latt thame leif in sorrow
Thair observance is angir pyne & cair
So sall thay feill I find thame god to borrow
O blisfull god how mony lusty morrow
thow hes me granttit in appryll Iune and may
ane hard weird was laid the man a forrow
That all his tyme had nevir a mirry day
Ffinis [etc]
Author unknown

head.title: Co[m]monyng betuix the mester and the heure

lg.l: Lord god my hairt is in distres
and wrappit full of havines
and I as wofull presoneir
Gois walking vp and doun In weir
my lady will not on me blent
that movis me maist in myne entent
daly in point to fall in swoun
ay sen the court come to þe toun
I said to hir my darling deir
my luve my hairt and all my cheir
the conforting of all my cair
quhe[n] pleisis ȝow I mak repair
Tell me ȝour mynd & nothing lane
my hairt with ȝow sall ay remane
In to myne eir tha[n] cowld scho roun
Byd quhill the court be of the toun
I said to hir my speciall luve
my mind fra ȝow sall nevir remve
Scho a[n]serit me bot not displesit
at this tyme ȝe ma not be eisit
I sichet tha[n] and said allace
can ȝe not fynd na tyme or place
quhair I may quitly lay ȝow doun
na not quhill court be of the toun
Quhy say ȝe so my awin sweit thing
knaw ȝe not weill and I war king
that I wald evir ȝow plesour do
and daly reddy þairvnto
with evir (^ with dot above, [wt ȝow] in margin) for to remane
Sowld ȝe not play the counter pane
Scho said to me ga glaik ȝow loun
The court is new cum to þe toun
Than said I wt ane dolerus mone
ȝe brek my hairt my bony one
My travell I may think ill sett
gif I no mair kyndnes ȝit gett
ȝe gart me trow or thay war gane
ȝe lovit me best of any ane
quhat ailis ȝow now for to luik doun
Becauss the court is in the toun
I said my hairt not ȝow to greve
Sa sone I will not taik my leve
To me ȝe sowld not be vnkynd
my hony my Ioy remord ȝour mynd
I hald me speciall for ȝor ma[n]
with all the serwice that I can
now grant me this my birdy broun
Na byd quhill court be of the toun
Ga hyne q scho methink ȝe vary
ourlang with tratlingis me ȝe tary
Now ȝit my langour for to less
my gentill Io gif me a kiss
It is ourlait to schute me owte
Thane byd and tak ȝour sait abowt
ȝe salbe servit for a croun
howbeit the court be in the toun
Thus I ouirdraif fra day to day
To spy quhen court sowld gone away
quhill of hir luve my langour was gane
I had provydit ane bonyar ane
Syne met hir I spak with befoir
weill plestert vp in the glengoir
quha had bene flamet and new laid doun
Lang or the court ȝeid of the toun
Ffinis [etc]
Author unknown

head.title: Off luve

lg.l: Luve þat is het can no skill
luve þat is cald can be still
Luve þat is peure wat mekle pyne
Luve þat is riche Is eith to tyne
Luve with denger Is deir bocht
Luve þat chaingis dow richt nocht
Luve þat is trew lestis ay
Luve þat is fals wenttis away
ane vþir
Author unknown

head.title: Sum ma[n] luvis for leill luve and delyte

lg.l: Sum ma[n] luvis for leill luve and delyte
and vþir sum for rentis and renoun
Sum ma[n] luvis for gold and siluer quhyt
and vþir sum in way of saluatioun
and Sum ma[n]is luvis be wey of (ded, struck through) destructioun
oure all the laive þat is the werst I wene
Luve god our all thy nichbour nixt esteme
[etc]
Author unknown

head.title: Ffurth ouer the mold at morrow as I ment

lg.l: Ffurth ouer the mold at morrow as I ment
Wwithowttin feir To tak the helsum air
I saw ane berne abbydying on the bent
Toward the place quhair I past to repair
his fresche effeir maid all the feildis fair
I was agast to pass in his presence
nocht knawing how to do till him revere[n]ce
Bot neuirtheles I had so hett desyre
for to haif knawin quhat persone it sowld be
I went a[n]none to him for till Inquyre
with cap in hand first kneland on my kne
on guid maner agane he salute me
and said my freind Cum set ȝow doun me by
wylcome ȝe bene To beir me cumpany
To mak rehersall of his riche array
or for to blasone his abilȝeme[n]t
Sowld tyne the tyme and dryve away the day
Thairfoir I think it not expedie[n]t
for I wald schaw ȝow schortly myne Entent
I sperit his name and he said panderus
That sumtyme servit the gud knycht troyelus
I said to him ser gife ȝe be pandarus
glaidly of ȝow I wald haif commonyng
questionis of luve that can ȝe weill discus
Thairfoir wald I Inquyre of ȝow a thing
To speik of luve Suppois I be not ding
I pray ȝow ser ffra me ȝe nocht conceill
Quhen ladeis to thair luvaris salbe leill
pandarius
He said my sone ȝour questioun Is obscure
Bot gif I can I sall it sone declair
In all egipt quhe[n] non Is fundin peure
and in to rome ar fund no wrangus air
Quhen þat no woma[n] desyris to be fair
and quhen the law, leiffis no man to appeill
Than ladyis to thair luvaris salbe leill
Quhen þat no fische is fundin in the flude
and malt and meill ar maid withottin millis
and quhe[n] the bak aboundis In to blude
Moir than the hair that ry[n]nis to the hillis
and quhen that weme[n] ȝarnis not thair willis
and mvssill schellis gevis moir money tha[n] meill
Than ladeis to thair luvaris salbe leill
Quhen firn flurichis and beiris gude frute
and gud reid wyne growis on the roddyne treis
and on the hadder growis the hassill nvte
hony and walx ar maid but werk of beis
and the falcoun can fang no fowle bot fleis
and quhen the theivis thinkis schame to steill
Than ladyis to thair luvaris salbe leill
I said him sir that tyme may nevir (be, struck through) cum
That thir foirspokkin thingis may be trew
and he said nay Thay salbe all and sum
seurly afoir the questioun thow me schew
heirfoir my freind as for this tyme adew
heir to remane na langer Is me lent
Ffurth ouir the mold at morrow thus I went
Ffinis q Stewart

head.title: Ane vþir ballat of vnpossibiliteis co[m]paird to the trewth of wemen in luve

lg.l: Quhen þat the mone hes dominatioun
aboif the sone in mydis of someris day
Quhen abirdene and air ar baith a toun
and tweid sall turne and ry[n]nis in to tay
and quhe[n] the bass fleittis to the yle of may
Quhen p[ar]radyce Is quyt of hevinly hew
Scho quhome I luve sall steidfast be and trew
Quhe[n] that In Iune In sessone Is the oister
till all me[n]nis meit and fische ar nocht in see
and quhe[n] invy Is flemit owt of cloister
and fische with fy[n]nis can in the firmame[n]t fle
Quhen lichtleit ar leisingis and luvit is lawtie
and Inglische tungis translaitit ar in grew
Scho quhome I luve sall steidfast be & trew
At midsyumer quhen frossin Is the feild
and februar flwreist with all (þ[er], struck through) flowris
And quhe[n] the hound Levis the hairis feild
quhe[n] fynall end Is maid of all labowris
quhen tyme Is recknit wtowttin ony houris
and quhen the taid eitis nothing bot the rew
Scho quhome I luve sall steidfast be & trew
Quhen evirilk ([Ilk] struck through, [cuntry] above) land and regioun
at ane accord ar sett but varience: quhe[n] wra[n]gus deidis neidis no reformatioun
quhen yre but mesure and also grit constance
In a persone ar Ionit with temperance
Quhen the reid rose of natur becu[m]is blew
scho quhome I luve sall steidfast be and trew
Quhen that the schip may sicker saill but steir
quhe[n] men beis borne to byid heir Immortall
Quhe[n] glass and gold allyk ar fundin deir
and every lord ([has] struck through, [settis] above) land but ferme or male
and quhe[n] als swyft as swallow beis the snale
quhe[n] troy agane Is biggit fair & new
Scho quhome I luve sall steidfast be and trew
Ffinis [etc]
Author unknown

head.title: Ane vþ[er] ballat of vmpossibiliteis

lg.l: Quhen phebus in to þe west rysis at morrow
and in the eist gois doun befoir the nicht
and quhen the mirk mone misteris nocht to borrow
at the bricht sone nowder hait nor licht
Quhen saturne Is warme and venus wicht
and quhen all gilt is of this warld ago
Than sall my lady luve me & no mo
Quhen þat I may governe appryll fra showris
and fabruar fra frost and fellone flawis
and may to burgeoun herbis fair & flowris
and stay wyseme[n] to study on the lawis
and vane Ianglaris to be but dowbill sawis
and Ielosy to be no luvaris fo
Than sall my lady luve me & no mo
Quhen the ochellis ar flittit over the ferry
and loch levin ry[n]nis over the eist lowmond
and gud wyne growis on the brwmill berry
and tay and tweid ar temit to þe grund
and bellis quhe[n] thay ar rungin hes no sound
and quhen the wind Is stable, and still standis so
Than sall my lady luve me & no mo
Quhe[n] þat forth turnis and ry[n]nis to þe hill
and everilk moss ar maid in gude domane
and quhe[n] the sie will nathir (ser, struck through)eb nor fill
and all montanis ar turnit In to plane
Quhe[n] forssy fluiddis rysis for no rane
and quhe[n] gud corne growis ryp wtowttin stro
Than sall my lady luve me & no mo
Quhen bairnis and birdis thair willis ȝairnis (nevir? struck through, [no] above) deill
and wemen ar sett to say no ma[n] a miss
and quhen fals fortoun movis not hir quheill
and me[n] may conqueiss kindomis with a wiss
Quhen hevin Is tome and hell is full of bliss
and quhen the riche for sufficience sayis ho
Than sall my lady luve me and no mo
Ffinis [etc]
Author unknown

head.title: My hairt is gone, confort is none

lg.l: My hairt is gone, confort is none,
To luve I may complene
That to haif luvit, and be refusit,
and na trewth fund agane
(Hes, struck through) My luve quhilk I, hes seruit trewly
with hairt and all my micht
So hecht scho me, Trew for to be,
Tharto hir faith scho plicht,
Sen trewth is nocht, in wemen wrocht
Bot fals vnstabilnes
I sall thame ay, dispyt alway
and thame set by the les
My lady fair, quhilk þat þis cair,
Into my hairt hes wrocht
promittit me, Trew for to be,
In word in deid, and thocht
Credence I gaif, aboif the laif,
vnto þat frely fair
bot now I may, dispone alway,
at hir falsheid to lair
Eftir that fre, I say for me
quhill þt I leif on lyfe
ful fals of fay, both nicht and day
I sall hald maid & wyfe
ȝe me[n] þat ar, in lusty fare
and thinkis luvaris to be
behald & heir ellis at thame leir,
for to be fals and sle
Sett not ȝour luve on thame abuve
Bot as ȝe fynd cawss Is
for & thay sie, that trew ar ȝie
Thay will grow wyld I wiss
And fickilnes, war tynt I gess
and all distroyit trow I
In to this grund, It sowld be fund
In wemen by and by
I tak my leif, all in a greif
at hir þat Is vntrew
both nicht and day, I sing and say
adew fals luve adew
Ffinis
Author unknown

head.title: Ane aigit ma[n] twyss fourty ȝeiris

lg.l: Ane aigit ma[n] twyss (twy[n]ty, struck through) fourty ȝeiris
Eftir the halydayis of ȝule
I hard him say amangis the freiris
of ordour gray makand grit dule
Rycht as he wer a fowriuss fule
oft syiss he sicht and said allace
Be chryst my cair ma nevir cule
That evir I serwit mowth thankless
Throt ignorance and foly ȝowth
my preterit tyme I wald nevir spair
Plesans to put in to þat mowth
quhill eild said fule latt be thy fair
and now my heid is quhyt and hair
for feding of þat fowmart face
Quhairfoir I mvrn bayth laitt and air
That evir I serwit mowth thankless
Gold and siluer þat I micht gett
Brochis beisandis robbis and ringis
Ffrely to gife I wald not lett
To pleiss tha mullis attour all thingis
Rycht as the swan for sorrow singis
Befoir hir deid ane littill space
Rycht so do I and my handis wringis
That evir I seruit mowt tha[n]kless
Bettir it war ane ma[n] to serf
wt wirchep and honor vndir a scheild
nor hir to pleiss Thot thow suld sterf
That will not luke on the in eild
Ffra þat thow haif no hair to heild
Thy heid fra harmy[n]g þat it hess
Quhen pen and (pus, struck through) purss and all is peild
Tak thair a meiss of mowth tha[n]kless
And in example it may be sene
The grund of trewt quha vndirstude
Ffra in thy bag thow beir thyne Ene
Thow gettis no grace bott Ffor thy gud
at venus closet for to conclude
Call ȝe not thiss ane kankert caiss
now god help and the haly rude
And keip all ma[n] Ffra mowth tha[n]kless
O brukill ȝowth in tyme behald
and in thyne hairt thir wirdis graif
or thy complexioun gadder cald
Amend thy miss thy self to saif
The hevy[n]is bliss gif thow wilt haif
and of thy gilt remit and grace
all this I hard ane auld ma[n] raif
(eftir þe ȝule) of mowth tha[n]kless
q ke[n]nedy

div.head: Follows ballattis of the prayiss of wemen and to þe reproche of vicious men

head.title: The thrid pairt of luve to the reproche of fals vicius men and prayiss of guid wemen
Allace so sobir is the micht

lg.l: Allace so sobir is the micht
of weme[n] for to mak debait
Incontrair menis subtell slicht
quhilk ar fulfillit wt dissait
wt tressone so intoxicait
ar me[n]nis mowthis at all houris
Quhome in to trest no woma[n] wait
Sic perrell lyis in paramoris
Sum sueris that he luvis so weill
That he will de wtout remeid
Bot gife þat he hir freindschip feill
That garris him sic langour leid
and thot he haif no doubt of speid
ȝit will he sich and schaw grit schouris
as he wald sterfe in to þat steid
Sic p[er]rell lyis in paramoris
Athis to sueir and giftis to hecht
moir than he hes thretty fold
and for hir honour for to fecht
quhill þat his blude be cu[m]in cold
Bot fra scho to his willis ȝold
adew fair weill thir somer flouris
all growss in glass that semit gold
Sic p[er]rell lyis in paramouris
Than turnis he his saill a[n]none
And passis to ane vþir port
Thot scho be nevir so wo begone
Hir cairis cauld ar his confort
Heirfoir I pray in termys schort
Crhyst keip thir birdis bricht in bowris
Fra fals luvaris and thair resort
Sic perrell lyis in paramoris
Ffinis q m[er]sar

head.title: Ffollowis the l[ett]re of cupeid

lg.l: Cupeid vnto quhois commandiment
The gentill kinreid of the goddis sa hye
and people infernall bene obedient
And all mortall folk servin buselye
Off the goddis sone Sytherea onlye
To all thame ȝat to our deitie
Bene subiectis / hairtty greting send we
In generall we will þat ȝe knaw
That ladyis of honour and of reuerens
and vþir gentill wemen having saw
Sic seid of complaynt in our audiens
Of men þat done þame outtrage and offens
That it our eiris grevith for to heir
So peteus is the effect of this mateir
Passing all landis / on the little yle
þat clepid is a ione thay most complayne
Thay say þat thair is crop and rute of gyle
Sa can tha man dissymmill and fayne
Wᵗith standing droppis in thair eye twayne
Quhen þat thair hairtis feilis no distreß
To blindyn wemen wᵗith thair dowbilneß
Thair wordis spoken be so sichinglye
Wᵗith peteous cheir and countenance
That every wicht þat menith trewlye
Demyß þat thay in hart haif sic grevance
That say so Importable in thair pennance
Bot gif thair lady list to schaw þame grace
Thay will annone stervin in þat place
say thay
Ah lady myne a mark here indicates the insertion of the 'say thay' in the margins I ȝow Insure
As I haif grace so sall I evir be
Quhill þat my lufe may lest & indure
To ȝow als hummill and law in ilk degree
As possible is and keip all thingis as secre
ryᵗght as ȝour self list þat I do
Or ells my hart I wald it brist in two
Full hard it is to knaw a manis hairt
for outward may no man the trewᵗ deme
quhen word out of mowᵗ may none stert
Bot it by resone semyd ilk wicht to quene
So it is said of hairt as it wald seme
O faythfull woman full of Innocens
Thow art dissauid be fals apparens
By proceß movith oft womanis pete
Wenyng all thingis wer thaiß men say
That grant thame grace of thair benignite
ffor þat men suld noᵗ for thair saik dey
And wᵗith gud hairt dois sett thame in þe way
of blissfull lufe keip it gife thay cone
And thus vthir wᵗith wyle wemen bene ywone
And quhen þis man the pan hais by the steil
And fully is in his posssesioun
Wᵗith þat woman cuvith he no moir to deill
Eftir gude he may fynd in the toun
ony woman his blind effection
Vnto bestow Evill mot he preve
A man for all othes is hard to beleve
And for þat every fals man hes a maik
Quhan this traitour this woman does forsaik
He fast speidis him vnto his fellow
Till he be thair his hairt is on a low
His fals deceit may him noᵗ suffyce
Bot of his tressone telleth all the wyse
Is this a fair awaunt in this honour
A man accuß him self and so defame
Is it goid to confeß him self a tratour
And bring a woman to a sklanderouß name
and tell how he hir body hes done schame
No wirschep may he thus to him conquere
Bot grit disklandir vnto him him and hir
To hir, nay, ȝit wes it no reprefe
for all for vertew was þat scho wrocht
Bot he þat brewit hes all this mischeif
That spak to fair / and falsly inward thoᵗ
His be þe sklandir As it by resson ocht
And vnto him thank perpetuall
That in such a neid help can so well
All thoᵗ throw menis slycht and subtelte
A silly symple and Innocent woman
Betrayed is / noᵗ windir is sen the citie
of troy as the story tell can
Betrayid wes throw the dissait of man
and sett on fyre and all doun owirthraw
and fynaly destroyit as men knaw
Betray not men citeis and grit kingis
quhat wicht is it can schaip remedy
Againß thais falsly purposid thingis
Quho can the craft suche craft to espy
Bot man quhois wit is evir reddy to apply
To thing þat sownyng is to falshed
Woman be wer of fals men I red
And forthirmoir hes thay men in visage
That quhair thay not lykly bene to speide
Sic as they bene wᵗith a dowble visag
Thay procurin for to persew thair neid
He prayith him in his cauß to proceid
And lergly guerndonyth he his travaill
Littill wot wemen how men thame assaill
Anothir wreche vnto his fallow saith
Thow fischeiß fair Scho þat the hes fyrid
Is fals inconstant and hes no faith
Scho for the raid of folk is so desyrid
and as an horß fro day to day scho is hyrid
That quhen thow twynniß fro hir cumpany
Cummes a nowthir and blerit is thyne E
Now pick on fast and ryd thy Iurney
quhill thow art thair ffor scho behind thy back
So liberall is scho will no thing wᵗith say
bot smartly of a nothir tak a smak
Thus fariß theis wemen all the pak
Quho so thame trestiß hangit mot they be
evir thay dissyre change and novelte
Quhairof procedis this bot of invy
for he him self hir win na may
he speikith hir repreif and villany
as manis bakbytting toung is wont alwey
Thus diverß men full oft mak assay
for to disturb folk in syndre wyse
for thay may noᵗ obtene þair interpryse
Mony one eik wald for no gude
That hes in luve his tyme spent and vsid
men wist þat his lady asking wᵗstude
or þᵗ he wer of hir planely refusid
lg.note: Written in margin as an addition to line 122, denoted by symbol
lg.l: Or west in vane all þat he had misvsid
Quhairfor he can none vþir remedy
Bot on his lady schapis him to lie
Every woman he sayith is licht to get
Can none say nay gife scho be weill ysocht
Quho so may laysir haif wᵗith hir to trete
of his purpoiß sall he faill nocht
Bot he on madneß be so deip brocht
That he schend all wᵗith oppin homelineß
That lovin wemen thay dottin as I geß
To sklandir wemen thus quhat may profeit
To gentilneß named that thame arme sould
In defens of wemen And thame delyte
As that the ordour of gentilneß wold
gif þat a gentill man list gentill to be hol
He most all eschew þat þairto is necessary
A sklandrous toung is his grit adversary
A foule vyce is of tong to be licht
ffor quho so much clappis grabbit oft
The toung of man so swift is and so wicht
That quhen it is raysid up on loft
lg.note: WTR transcribes this as vpon
lg.l: Resson is schewin so slawly and soft
That it him nevit ourtak may
Lord so thatis men bene trusty in assay
All beit that men fynd on woman nyce
Inconstant rekleß or variable
Dengerous prowd fulfillit of malyce
Wᵗithout fayth or lufe and dissavable
Sle queynt fals in all vntrust culpable
Wickit ferß or full of crewelty
ȝit follois noᵗ that sic all wemen be
Quhen the hie god angellis formyd had
among thame all wair I speirnoᵗ deleted in main line of text here none
That fundin wes malicios and bad
ȝis all men watt thair wer mony ane
That for thair pryd fell fra the hevin anone
Suld men thairfor gif all angellis prowd name
Nay he þat mereitis is to blame
Off twell apostols ane a tratour was
The remnant ȝit gud wer and traw
So gif it hap men fynd percaiß
A woman fals Suche gude is to eschew
And deme noᵗ þat thay all þairfoir be vntrew
I se weill menis awin falsneß
thame causis wemen for to trust the leß
O every man aucht haif a hairt tendir
Vnto a woman and deme hir honorable
Quhithir his schap be thik or sklendir
or he be gude or bad it is no fable
every wicht wot þat wit hes ressonable
That of a woman he descendit is
Than is it schame of hir to speik a miß
A wicket tre gude fruct may none furᵗ bring
for suche the frute is as is the tree
Tak hed of quhome thow tuke the begynnyng
Lett thy muther be mirroʳ vnto th
Honoʳ hir gife thow wald honorit be
Dispyß hir than not in no maner
Lest þat þairby thy wickednes appere
Ane auld prowerb said is in inglische
That bird or fowll is full dishonest
quhat evir he be and hald full churliche
That vsis to defoull his awin nest
Men to say weill of wemen it is best
And noᵗ to dispyß thame nor depraue
Gif thay will thair honoʳ keip and saue
The ladeis evir complene thame on clerkis
That thay haif maid bukis of þair defame
In quhilk thay dispyß wemen and þair werkis
And speik of thame grit repreif and schame
And causles gife thame a wicket name
Thus thay dispysid be on euvery syd
Disklanderit and blawin on out full wyd
Tha sary bukis makis mention
Hown wemen betryit in speciall
adam david sampson and salamon
and mony mo quho may reherß thame all
The tressone þat thay haif done and sall
The warld thair malice may noᵗ comprehend
As clerkis say for it hes none end
Ovid in his bukis callit remedy
of lufe Grit reprufe of wemen wrytiß
Quhairin I trow he did grit foly
And every wicht þat sic caifß delytiß
A clerkis custome is quhen he wrytiß
of wemen be it prose rym or verß
Say thay be wicked all knaw heHere the word 'thay' is deleted the reverß
And that buk scollaris lernid in thair chyldheid
For thay of wemen bewar suld in age
and to Luve them evir be in dreid
Sen to dissaif is sett all thair curege
That say of perell man suld cast the awantage
Namely of sic as men Here a word is deleted - 'bene'? haif bene inwrappid
ffor mony a man by wemen haif mischappid
No chairge is quhat theis clerkis sane
of all thair wryting I do no cure
All thair lawbour and travell is in van
ffor betwene me and my lady nature
Sall noᵗ be sufferid quhill the warld indure
Thus theis clerkis by thair crewall tyranny
On silly wemen kythin thair maistry
Quhylome for mony of þame were in my chene
Tyed / and now for unweildy age
And vnlust may nocht to luve attane
And sane now þat lufe is boy verry dotege
Thus for thay thame self lakin curege
Thay folk excyt by þair wicked sawis
For to rebell agains me and my lawis
Bot mawgir thame that blame wemen most
Suche is the forß of myne impressioun
That sodanly I can feill thair bost
And all þair wrong Imaginatioun
It sall noᵗ be in thair ellectioun
The fowlest slute in all the toun to refuse
Gif þat me list ffor all þat they can muse
Bot hir in hairt in hairt as brynnyng desyre
as thoᵗ scho wer a duches or quene
So can I folkis hairtis sett on fyre
And as me list send tham Ioy or tene
Thay þat to wemen be quhet so kene
My scharp persing persing strokis how thay smyt
sall feill and knaw how þai do kerue and byt
Perde this clerk this subteill ouyde
And mony ane vþir dissauit has be
of wemen as it is knawn full wyd
That no man moir / and þat is grit dente
So excellent a clerk wes he
And vþir mo þat coldin full weill preiche
Betrappid war for oft þat thay could teche
And trust ȝe weill þat it is no mervell
for wemen knawin planely thair intent
Thay wait how softly thay can thame assail
And quhat falsheid thay in thair hairtis ment
And thus tho clerkis in thair dengir hent
Wᵗith wennome an nother is distroyd
And thus theis clerkis wer oftin annoyd
Theis ladeis nor thir gentillis nevirþeleß
Were none of tho þat wrocht in this wyse
Bot suche as wer vertewleß
Thay quittin thus theis auld clerkis wyse
To clerkis leß ocht suffys
Than to dispraue wemen generally
ffor wirchep sall thay get none þairby
Gife þat theis men that luveris thame pretend
To wemen war fayᵗfull gude and trew
And dred them to dissaif or to offend
Wemen to lufe thame wald noᵗ eschew
Bot every day hes man ane harte new
ffor it WTR does not transcribe but MS shows text reading 'on and a quhyle' can noᵗ abyde a quhyle
Quhat forß is it sic ane to begyle
Men beir eik wemen vpone hand
That lichtly and wᵗithout ony pane
Thay wemen be / that can no wicht wᵗithstand
That his diseiß list to þame complene
Thay be so fraill Thay may thame noᵗ refrane
That quho so lykis that may thame lichtly haif
So be thair hairtis eisy in to graif
To Mr Iohine de mone as I suppoiß
That it wes a lewd occupatioun
In making of þe romant of the roiß
So mony a sle Imaginnatioun
And perllis for to rollin vp and doun
The long Poces So mony a slyᵗ cautell
for to dissaif a silly dammosell
Not can I say nor my wit comprehend
That art / payne / and subtelte suld faill
ffor to conqueir and some mak ane end
Quhan man a feble plaice sall assail
And sone also to winqueiß A battell
of quihilk no wicht may mak resistance
Nor hairt hes none to mak ony defence
Than mote follow of necessitie
Sen art askis so grit ingyne and pane
a woman to dissaif quhat so scho be
Off constance be thay noᵗ so barrane
As that some of theis clerkis sane
Bot thay be as wemen ocht to be
Sad constant and fulfillit of petie
How freindly wes medea to Iasone
In conquering the flece of gold
How falsly quite he hir trew affectioun
By quhome victory he gat as he wold
how may this man for schame be so bold
To falsin hir þat fra his deth and schame
him saift and gat him so grit pryß and nam
Off trowy also the tratour Eneas
The faithles aith how he him forsuore
To dydo the quene of cartage waß
That him relevit of his smertis soir
Quhat gentelneß mycht scho do moir
Than scho wᵗith hairt vnfenȝeid to him kydde
And wuhat mischeif to hir heirof eftir betydde
In my legend of naturis men may find
Quho so lykis therin for to reid
That aith nor behest may man bind
off repruvable schame haif thay no dreid
In manis hairt trewᵗ hes no steid
lg.note: Differs from Hoccleve's line
lg.l: The soill is noᵗ thair may no trewᵗ grow
To wemen namely it is noᵗ unknown
Clerkis sane also thair is no malice
Vnto wemenis wicket crabbitneß
O woman how sall thow thy self chywyce
Sen men of the suche harme witneß
Bewar wemen of thair fikilneß
Keip thyne awin quhat men clap or crak
And sum of thame sall smart I vndirtak
Mallyce of wemen quhat is it to dreid
Thay slay no man nor distroyis no ceteis
Nor oppreß folk nor ovirlaid
Betray Impyris realmys or ducheß
Nor birnys men thair landis nor mees
Enpusone folk nor houß sett on fyre
Na falso contractis mak for no hyre
Trust perfyt luve entyre cherite
fervent will and entalentid curage
All maner gud as settis weill to be
Haif wemen evir of custome and vsage
And weill thay cone menis yre assuaige
Wᵗ soft wirdis discreit and benyng
Quhat thay be inward thay schaw vtward by sing
Wemen hairt vnto no crewalte
inclynid is bot thay be cheritable
peteouß devoit full of humylite
Schamefast debonar and amiable
Dreidfull and of wordis mesurable
Quhat wemen theis haif not perauenture
fowith not the way of þair nature
Men sane our first muder nathele
Maid all mankynd leiß his libertie
and maid him wᵗithout Ioy doutleß
for goddis haistis dissobeyit sche
Quhan scho presomid to test of the tre
That God forbyd þat scho eith þairof suld
and nor had noᵗ bene the diuill nomoir scho wold
The invyous suelling þat þe feind oʳ fo
Had vnto man in hairt for his welth
Sent a serpent and maid hir for to go
To dissaif Eue and thus wes manis welth
Bereft him by the feind in stelth
The woman noᵗ knowing of þat dissait
God watt full fer wes it frome hir consait
Quhairfor I say this gude woman Eue
our fader Adame dissait nocht
Thair may no man for dissait it preue
propirly / Bot þat scho in hairt and thoᵗ
Had it compassid first or scho it wrocht
And for suche wes noᵗ hir intentioun
Men may it call no dissait of hir by ressoun
Nor no wicht dissauis but he purpose
The feind this dissait kest and noᵗ sche
Than is it wrong to deme or suppoiß
That of his harme scho suld the cauß be
Wyte the feynd And his be þe mawgre
And in ecusation haif hir Innocens
Saif only þat scho brak obediens
And twiching this full few men þair be
Vnnethes ony dar I saifly say
ffro the day to day as men may all day se
Bot þat the best of god thay dissobey
Haif this in mynd siris I ȝow prey
Gife þat ȝe be discreit and ressonable
ȝe will hir hold the moir excusable
And quhair men say in man is steidfastneß
And wemen is of þair curage vnstable
Quho may of adame beir such a witneß
Tellith me this / was he noᵗ chengeable
Thank bothe wer in one caiß semblable
Saif willing þe fein dissuaid Eue
And so did scho noᵗWTR notes that the Hunterian Club specifies Adam here by ȝour leive
ȝit was this syn syn happe to mankynd
The feind dissauid was for all his slich
Ffor aucht he cowd him i[n] his slichtis wind
Ffor his trespass come from the hevin on hicht
god to dischairge ma[n] of his wecht
flesche and blude tuk of a virgyne
and ssufferith deth him to deliu[er] frome pyne
And god to quhome thair may no thing hid be
Gife he in weme[n] had knawin suche malice
As me[n] record þame in generalte
off our lady of lyfe reperatryce
nold haif bene borne bot that scho of (h, struck through) vyce
was woyd, and full of vertew weill he wist
Endewid of hir to be borne (I w, struck through) him list
Hir he aped vertew haith sic excellence
That all to leif his ma[n]is faculte
To declair it and þairfoir in suspence
hir dew preysing put neidis most be
Bot thiss I say (þat, struck through) veraly that sche
Is blissit of god to quhois sone belongith
The key of m[er]cy by his girdill hongith
And of m[er]cy hes every ma[n] suche neid
That lesing þat fairweill the joy of ma[n]
and of thair power now takith richt gude heid
he m[er]cy may weill and purchess can
displeiss hir not honor that woma[n]
and vþir weme[n] all for hir saik
and but ȝe do ȝor sorrow sall awaik
In ony buk also quhair ca[n] ȝe find
That of the werkis of deth or of lyfe
of jesu spellith or makith ony mynd
That weme[n] him forsuk for wo or stryfe
Quhair wes thair ony wicht so intencyfe
about him as wass woma[n] provid none
The appostillis him forsokin every one
Weme[n] forsuke him, not for all the faith
of holy churche in woma[n] left only
This is no leis ffor this holy writ saith
Luke and ȝe sa find it so hardely
and þairfoir I may weill preif þ[er]by
That in woma[n] regnith stable co[n]stance
and in me[n] is the chenge of variance
Thow precius jem of martiris m[er]garet
That of thy blude dreidis non effusioun
Thow luver trew thow madin mansueit
Thow constant woma[n] in thy passioun
ouircome the feindis temptatioun
and mony a wicht conuertit thy doctrene
vnto þe faith of holy god thow virgyne
Bot vndirstand this I only co[m]mend hir nocht
By enchesone of hir virginite
Trusteth it come nevir in to thot
Ffor ever wer I aganis chestite
and evir sall Bot lo this movith me
hir loving hairt and constant to hir lay
Dryfe out of reme[m]brance I ne may
Now haldith this for ferme and for no le
That this trew and iust co[m]mendatioun
of weme[n], tell I for no flattry
ne becaus of pryd or elatioun
Bot only lo for this intentioun
To gife þame curege of p[er]seuera[n]ce
In vertew, and hir honour till awa[n]ce
The moir vertew the less is the pryd
vertew so digne is and so noble in kynd
That vyce and he in feir will not abyd
He putteth vycis clene out of his mynd
he fleith fro thame he levis thame behind
O woma[n] þat of vertew art hostress
Grit is thy honor and thy wortheness
Than will I thus conclud and defyne
we ȝow co[m]mand our mynisteris echone
That reddy ȝe be our haistis to inclyne
That of theiss fals me[n] our rebell fone
ȝe do punysme[n]t and þat a[n]none
woyd thame our court and baneiss thame for evir
So þat thairin moir cum thay nevir
Ffulfillit be it ([cessing] written over [sesing]) all delay
Luk thair be none excusatioun
writtin in the lusty mow[n]th of may
In our paleiss quhair mony a millioin
off luvaris trew haif habitatioun
The ȝeir of grace joyfull and jocound
a thowsand four hundreth and the secound
Ffinis q chauseir

head.title: All tho þat list of wemen evill to speik

lg.l: All tho þat list of wemen evill to speik
and say of thame wer than thay deserue
I pray to god þat þair nekkis do brek
or on sum evill deth mot thay jangleris sterue
for every ma[n] ar haldin thame to serue
and do þame wirschep honor and seruyss
In every man[er] þat thay best ca[n] devyss
Ffor we aucht first to think on quhat maner
Thay bring ws furth and quhat pane thay indure
first in our birth and syne fro ȝeir to ȝeir
how besaly thay haif done thair bussy cure
To keip ws fro every misauentur
In our ȝewth quhe[n] we haif no micht
our self to keip nathir by day nor nycht
Allaiss how may we say on thame bot weill
off quhome we wer fostred and yboir
and bene all our succour als trew as steill
and for our saik full oft thay suffir soir
wtout weme[n] wer all our joy loir
Quhairfoir we aucht all weme[n] till obey
In all gudeness I ca[n] no moir to say
This is weill knawin and hes bene or this
That weme[n] bene causs of all gudeness
off knychtheid nurtor eschewing all maliss
Incress of wirschep and of all worthiness
Thairto courtass meik and grund of fathfulness
Glaid and myrry and trew in every wyss
That ony gentill hairt can think or devyss
And thot ony wald trust to ȝour vntrewt
and to ȝour fair wordis wald ocht assent
In gude fayth me thinkis it wer grit rewt
That vþir weme[n] suld for thair gilt be schent
That nevir knew nor wist of þair intent
nor list not to heir the fair wirdis ȝe wryte
quhilk ȝe ȝow pane fro day to day to dyte
Bot quho may be war of ȝour taillis vntrew
That ȝe so busaly paynt and indyte
Ffor ȝe will sueir þat ȝe nevir knew
ne saw the woma[n] nowdir muche nor lyte
Saif only hir to quhome ȝe had delyte
as for to serf of all that evir ȝe say
and for þair lufe most ȝe neidis de
Than will ȝe sueir þat ȝe knew nevir befoir
Quhat lufe was nor his dreidfull obseruans
Bot now ȝe feill þat he ca[n] wound soir
Quhairfoir ȝe put ȝow in hir gou[er]nance
quhome luve hes ordeynid ȝow to do plesance
wt all ȝour mycht ȝour littill lyvis space
quhilk endis sone bot gif scho gif ȝow grace
And tha[n] to bed will ȝe sone draw
and soir seik ȝe will ȝow thane fane
and sueir fast ȝour lady hes ȝow slaw
and brocht ȝow sodanly in so heich a pane
Than fro ȝour deth may no ma[n] ȝow restrane
wt a dengerus luk of hir ene two
That to ȝour deth most ȝe neidis go
Thus will ȝe mvrne thus will ȝe sich soir
as thot ȝour hart a[n]none in two wald brist
and sueir fast þat ȝe may leif no moir
myne awin lady þat micht gife ȝe list
Bring myne harte sum deill vnto rest
as gife thow list m[er]cy on me to haif
Thus ȝour vntrewt will evir m[er]cy craif
Thus will ȝe plene thot ȝe no thing smert
Theis Innocent creaturis for to begyle
and sueir to thame how woundit is ȝour hert
for thair luve þat ȝe may leif no quhyle
Scarsly so long as on wald go a myle
So hyith deth to bring ȝow to ane end
Bot gif ȝour sou[er]rane lady list ȝow to ame[n]d
And gife for rewth scho confort ȝow in ony wyiss
for pety of ȝour fals othes seir
So þat Innoce[n]t wenyth þat it be as ȝow devyiss
and trowis ȝour hairt be as scho may heir
Thus for to confort and sum quhat do ȝow cheir
Tha[n] will thais jangleris deme of (ȝow) hir full ill
And say that ȝe hir haif fully at ȝor will
Lo how reddy thair toungis bene and prest
To speik harme of (h, struck through) weme[n] causless
allaiss quhy micht ȝe not als weill say the best
as for to deme thame thus giltless
In ȝor hairt I wis þair is to gentilness
That of ȝour awin gilt list thais weme[n] fame
now by my trewt me think ȝe be to blame
Ffor of woma[n] cu[m]myth this warldly weill
quhairfoir (h, struck through) we aucht to wirschep thame evirmoir
and thot it mischap on we aucht for to heill
for it is all thruch our fals loir
That day and nyt we pane ws evirmoir
wt mony ane aith thaiss weme[n] to begyle
wt fals taillis and mony a wickid wyle
And gif falsheid suld be reknit and tawld
In wemen, I wiss full trewt wer
not as in me[n] a thowsand fold
Ffro all vycis I wiss thay stond cleir
as in ony thing þat evir I cowd of heir
Bot gif intysting of theis men it mak
That thame to flattery ca[n]nyn nevir slak
I wald fane wit quhair evir ȝe cowd heir
wtout menis tysting a woma[n] did a miss
Ffor thair ȝe may get thame ȝe ly fro ȝeir to ȝeir
and mony a gabing ȝe mak to þame I wiss
for I cow nevir heir nor knawin or this
quhair evir ȝe cowd find in ony place
That evir woma[n] besocht ȝow of grace
Thair ȝe ȝow pane wt all ȝour full delyte
wt all ȝour hairt and all ȝour business
To pleiss thame both by day and nycht
Praying þame of thair grace and gentilness
To haif pety vpone ȝour grit distress
and þat thay wald on ȝour pane haif rewt
and slay ȝow not sen þat ȝe mene bot trewt
Thus may ȝe se þat thay bene (bot, struck through) fautless
and Innocent to all ȝour werkis sle
and all ȝour craft þat twich falsness
Thay knaw thame not nor may thame not espy
So sueir ȝe þat ȝe most neidis de
Bot gife thay wald of þair woma[n]heid
vpone ȝow rew or þat ȝe be deid
And than ȝour lady and ȝour hairtis quene
ȝe call thame and þairwt ȝe sich soir
and sayis my lady I trow þat it be sene
In quhat plyt þat I haif levit full ȝoir
Bot now I howp þat ȝe will no moir
In thais panis suffer me for to dwell
for of all gudness I wiss ȝe be the well
Lo heir a payntit process ca[n] ȝe mak
Theis harmeles creaturis for to be gyle
and quhen thay sleip ȝe pane ȝow to walk (^ with dot bove)
and to be think ȝow mony a cursid wyle
Bot ȝe sall se þe day þat ȝe sall curss the quhyle
That ȝe so busaly did ȝour Intent
Thame to begyle þat falsheid nevir me[n]t
Ffor this ȝe knaw weill thot I wold ly
In weme[n] is all trewt and steidfastness
for in gud fayth I ca[n] not of thame say
bot muche wirchep bounty and gentilness
ryt benyng fair and full of meikness
Gude and glaid and lawly I ȝow insure
Is this gudly angelik creature
And gif it hap a man be in diseiss
Scho dois hir bussines and hir full pane
wt all hir micht him to confort and eiss
Gif fro his diseiss scho mycht him restrane
In word nor deid ywiss scho will not fane
Bot wt all hir micht scho dois hir business
To bring him out of his haviness
Lo quhat gentilness thais weme[n] haif
Gife we culd knaw it for our rudness
How busy thay be ws to keip and saif
Both in heill and also in seikness
and alwey ryt sory for our distress
In every maner thuss schaw thay rewth
That in thame is all gudness and trewth
And sen we fynd in thame ge[n]tilness and trewt
wirschep bonty and kyndnes evirmoir
Let nevir this gentilness thruch ȝour slewt
In þair kynd trewt be ocht forloir
That in weme[n] is and hes full ȝoir
ffor in reuere[n]s of the hevy[n]nis quene
we awcht to wirschip all weme[n] þat bene
Ffor of all creaturis þat evir wer get and born
Thus wot ȝe weill a woma[n] was the best
By hir sone wes recouerid the bliss þat we had lorne
And thruch hir sone sall we come to rest
and bene ysavit gife þat our (lyfe, struck through) self lest
quhairfoir me thinkis gif ȝe haif grace
we ochtin weme[n] honor in every place
Thairfoir I reid that to our lyvis end
Ffro this tyme furt quhill þat we haif space
quhair we haif trespassid persew to ame[n]d
praying chryst Iesu well of all grace
To bring ws vnto þat blisfull place
Quhair all gude weme[n] salbe in feir
In hevin aboif among the angellis cleir
Ffinis q chauseir

head.title: Ladeis be war, þat plesand ar

lg.l: Ladeis be war, þat plesand ar
to me[n]is appetyte
That ȝe not rew, þat ȝe thame knew
Throw þ[er] lust and delyte
Ffor mony me[n], ar evill to ken
þat luvis paramour
wt fenȝeit mynd, fals and vnkynd
Bringis ȝow to dishonor
Quhen thay haif ane, wt flattry tane,
begylit wt a trane
Then wt ane vddir, thay will co[n]siddir
and play þe contrar pane
Thay will promit, giftis rycht grit
and sueir thay luve ȝow best
ȝow to begyle wt mony wyle
Thair mynd takkis nevir rest
Thair hairtis ar sett wt ficcelness
for loif and not for lufe
ȝow to dissaif wt dowbilness
To ȝour schame and reprufe
O ladeis deir I ȝow requeir
thair fals and fenȝeit fair
latt ay go henss and tyne creddens
beleving þame no mair
finis q scott

head.title: For to declair the he magnificens

lg.l: For to declair the he magnificens
and grit bontie þat into ladeis Is
The wirdiness and vertewis excelle[n]s
The lawd þe bonte the bewty and þe bliss
my barbir toung is vnworthy I wiss
Bot not þe less my pen I will apply
To say þe suth thot eloque[n]s I miss
of femeneyne þe fame to fortefy
Thot awld dottaris addressit þair delyte
To dyt of ladeis þe defamatioun
na wirthy wicht suld sett his appetyte
To reid sic rollis of reprobatioun
Bot rathir mak plane proclamatioun
To gaddir all sic bybillis bissely
and in þe fyre mak þair locatioun
off femenyne the fame to fortefy
Ffor quho so list þe richt for to reherss
To gloir humane thay mak habilite
quhen me[n] ar sad at þame solace thay sers
as habitaklis of all humylite
Thay bring grit weiris to tranquilite
The malyce of me[n] thay meiss and pacify
To saule and bodeis bath vtilite
Thairfoir all me[n] thair fame suld fortefy
Thot ane p[er]sone had peciablie to spend
all mychtis movit wtin þe mappamound
wanting weme[n] (Is/his, struck through) his weilfair wer at end
wtout þair co[m]fort cair suld thame co[n]found
Quhair ladeis abydis Bliss dois ay abound
and quhair thay fle felicite gois by
But þair solace no sege may be sound
Thairfoir all me[n] thair fame suld fortefy
Sen god hes gra[n]tit þame sic gudliness
and formyit thame eftir sa fair fassoun
Syne put sa blumy[n]g bewty in þair fess
Quhy suld not me[n] hald þame of he renoun
Sen god hes gevin þame sa grit gwerdoun
and wt sic meiknes done þame magnify
Quhy suld me[n] mak to þame co[m]paresoun
Bot our alquhair thair famis to fortefy
Off mary myld the maid Immaculat
To fortefy of femeneyne þe fame
chryst wes incarnat and Incorporat
and nureist nyne monethis in hir wame
and eftir borne and bocht ws fro þe blame
of beliall þat brunt ws bitterly
That only act savis þame all fra schame
and our all qr þair fame dois fortefy
Ladeis þai ar of excelland valour
Ladeis ar digne to haif autorite
Ladeis ar clene of co[m]fortand cullor
Ladeis ar wyiss and full of verite
Ladeis ar me[n]is paradyiss erdly
Ladeis ar pla[n]tit full of purite
Thair foir all me[n] thair fame suld fortefy
War all þe erd peper and perchemeyne
and pe[n]nis war all treis erbis and flouris
and all þe sternis þat in þe lift dois scheyne
war in þis erd most ornat oratouris
The se wer ynk wt fresch fludis and schouris
all wer to small ane buke to edify
Ffor to contene of ladeis the honoris
and loving þat þair fame dois fortefy
Ffinis q stewart

head.title: Thir billis ar brevit to birdis in speciall

lg.l: Thir billis ar brevit to birdis in speciall
moir for lust nor ony gude lufe
I breif this bill to ȝow in generall
ladeis and mady[n]is þat ȝarnis fra reprufe
ȝow to conserf and als for ȝour behufe
That ȝe defend and keip ȝow fra dissait
and ȝow to teich all filthy lyfe to hait
ȝe mady[n]is fair þat ar for till avance
wtin þe breist of ȝour virginite (^ with dot above, [and ladeis als ȝe cheis ȝow nevir to cha[n]ce] in margin)
Lat nevir ȝour wit to ȝour will subiect bie
Quhilk may defame be to ȝor honestie
ȝe madyn fair þat or for till avance
wtin (ȝow, struck through) þe breist of ȝour virginite
and ladeis als ȝe cheiss ȝow nevir to chance
quhilk may defame do to ȝour honestie
Latt nevir ȝour wit to ȝor will subiect be
Bot haif in mynd for him þat deid on rude
quhat wirchep is to be fair and gude
Haif mynd how gude is to haif a gude name
and tha[n] na cryme sall ȝour grit wirchep fyle
haif mynd how bernis hes brocht birdis to blame
and latt na grome wt gabing ȝow begyle
Ffor every wrynk luk þat ȝe haif a wyle
Ffor every word be wyse I warne ȝow
quhair trew is ane sexty is not trew
And ȝe him trow þan ar ȝe all betrasit
Ffor wt thair tressone thay bring the to ane trane
To leif in lust he is so lasit
moir tha[n] he (he, struck through) hes to hecht he wilbe fane
Bot and ȝe gra[n]t him ony grace agane
Ffra he haif sped fairweill spowsing to speir
Ffor tha[n] is all ȝor wadding changeit in to weir
All is in weir gife evir ȝe wene to wed
fra he hes wrocht his will I warn ȝow weill
Thair is no berne will bring ȝow to his bed
Bot every ane will say so haif I feill
Lo quhair scho gois hes tred hir scho on heill
Than haif ȝe skayt and skorny[n]g ȝow to steir
Ffor thy in welth be wysly war of weir
Be war for weir latt nevir ȝor wit go wyld
Ffor every day ane sample may ȝe se
Scho þat is farest fra tyme hir fame be fyld
Thair will no berne be blyt of hir bewte
Bot ay ar skornand bayth he and he
Thuss I conclude suppoiss my wit be grene
Bewty but bonty is not wirth a prene
Ffinis q m[er]sar

head.title: Now of wemen this I say for me

lg.l: Now of wemen this I say for me
off erthly thingis nane may bettir be
Thay suld haif wirschep & grit honoring
off men aboif all vþir erthly thing
Ryt grit dishonour vpoun him self he takkis
In word or deid quha evir weme[n] lakkis
Sen þat of weme[n] cu[m]in all ar we
weme[n] ar weme[n] and sa will end and de
wo wirth þe fruct wald put þe tre to nocht
and wo wirth him rycht so þat sayis ocht
off woma[n]heid þat may be ony lak
or sic grit schame vpone him for to tak
Thay ws consaif with pane and be thame fed
wtin þair breistis þair we be boun to bed
Grit pane and wo and mvrny[n]g m[er]velluss
Into þair birth thay suffir sair for ws
Than meit and drynk to feid ws get we nane
Bot þat we sowk out of þair breistis bane
Thay ar þe confort þat we all haif heir
Thair may no ma[n] be till ws half so deir
Thay ar our verry nest of nvrissing
In lak of thame quha ca[n] say ony thing
That fowll his nest he fylis, and for thy
exylit he suld be of all gud cu[m]pany
Thair suld na wyiss man gif audie[n]ce
To sic ane wtout intellige[n]ce
chryst to his fader he had not ane ma[n]
Se quhat wirschep weme[n] suld haif tha[n]
That sone is lord þat sone is king of kingis
In hevin & erth his matie ay ringis
Sen scho hes borne him in hir halines
and he is well and grund of all gudnes
all weme[n] of ws suld haif honoring
Serwice and luve aboif all vþir thing
q dumbar

head.title: I think thir men ar verry fals and vane

lg.l: I think thir men ar verry fals and vane
That wemenis honor degraidis or (þ[er], struck through) estait
and thay deserf pvnitioun and pane
Quhen thay p[er]some in to þair vane co[n]sait
To say or do þat may þair fame defait
for wemen ar of sic tryvmphand gre
That aboif men thay haif awtoritie
Ffor quhy þe warld may weill p[er]saif & ken
That weme[n] tryvmphis in hie dignitie
and in all honor þai do p[er]fer men
In prude[n]s (in, struck through) constans and in nobilitie
and god þat knawis wemenis nobilitie
wass of ane woman born as ȝe ma reid
and not co[n]saivit be me[n]is polute seid
And quhen chryst Iesu raiss fra deid to lyif
Till holy weme[n] he did first appeir
Becauss of þair constans sup[er]latyif
Till his appostillis he drew not first neir
For men in till all maleiss hes no peir
ane ma[n] did sell jesus quhilk is or heid
and als be me[n] was crusifixt & deid
Sanct petir did thryiss Refuse & deny
Chryst Iesus befoir pilattis Trybunall
Bott wemen did confess him hardely
Quhen he wes accusit in cayphass hall
Syne to þe croce togiddir thay past all
Quhen he wes deid thay wemen tuke grit cure
To spyce his body in þe sepulture
I can not wrytt nor ȝit ma I reherss
The noble holy wemen that hes bene
The quhilkis in every vertew did co[n]verss
as in to dyverss volomis may be sene
matheyris virgenis and mony holy quene
as in þe goldin legend men may reid
and als plutar rehersss of þair deid
Ane awld proverb in storeis did I fynd
quhilk solone said that prudent ma[n] of witt
q he na ma[n] sould spitt aganis þe wynd
In dreid it cum on him þat did it spitt
This proverb signifeis be my pure witt
That me[n] þat sklanderis wemen to þ[er] defame
That same sklander Redoundis to þ[er] awin schame
Men ar ay reddy to schaw weme[n]is vyce
bot þ[er] awin vyce thay wald excuse & hyd
& ȝit howbeit þat me[n] mak it sa nyce
god will gud weme[n]is fame defend & gyd
The trew will schaw þe fructis qr werkis all tyd
in till all bukis þat I cowld fynd or reid
The crymes of me[n] dois weme[n]is vyce exceid
We may p[er]saif in storeis ane & vddir
how adame brak eternall goddis co[m]mand
and how caen slew Iust abell his bruder
and pharo kepit Israell in captiue band
nobagodonasar ȝe ma vndirstand
quha for his wicketness was made ane beist
& diu[er]ss kingis wes pvneist for incest
To tell of nerone and co[m]modius
quhilk wer suppreme heidis of all þe Impyre
and vþir emprioris owttragiouss
The quhilk patt holy me[n] to sowrd & fyre
To reherss all it will bott gar me tyre
quhilk daly did co[m]mit ane crewall cryme
Bot weme[n] did nevir sic thing all þair tyme
Quha wass mair crewall nor calligula
or philaris or dionisius
and quha hes done mair tressone nyt or da
nor did þe falss cedussar symon maguss
Quha did mair errasy nor arrius
wt þe evill sort of pelligrians alss
as to chafas non wes kend so falss
Siclyk annass that fenȝeit Ipocreit
and fals (p?, struck through) pilatt þat co[n]dampnit chryst to de
Paip Iuliane that fals paip of dispytt
wt vþir ma full of Idolatre
vnnvmerable þair is and sa salbe
off crewale vicius men in every toun
qlk bringis pure peple to co[n]fusioun
Ffor sum ar tyrantis Sum ar co[m]moun thevis
Sum mvrdresaris co[m]mittand homicyd
Sum ar wirkaris of all kynd of mischevis
Sum ar tratoris qr evir thay ga[n]g or ryd
& Sum to sathan ar bayt pilatt & gyd
Sum ar mensworne ffull of fals callu[m]nationis
and co[m]moun learis Inwe[n]tand accusationis
And ȝit howbeit sum weme[n] falt be cace
Be Ignorance or thruch grit libertie
ȝit men sowld not allage in to no place
Thatt all wemen ar of sic vilitie
p[er]ticular prefferris not vniuersalitie
howbeit ane hes bene temptit wt þe devill
That fallowis not þat all þe laif ar evill
Quhairfoir I m[er]vell þat men ar sa rud
for to detract gud weme[n] evin and morne
ar we not maid of weme[n]is flesch and blud
and in þair bosum we ar bred and borne
Thairfoir we sowld do þame na skaith nor skorne
all men þat gevis to weme[n] evill co[m]mend
I pray to god þat thay mak ane ill end
Ffinis q weddirburne

head.title: Ffra raige of ȝowt the rynk hes rune

lg.l: Ffra raige of ȝowt the rynk hes rune
and ressone tane the man to tune
The brukle body than is wune
and maid ane veschell new
Ffor than thruch grace he is begune
The well of wisdome for to kune
Than is his weid of vertew spune
Trest weill this taill Is trew
Ffor ȝowth and will ar so consorss
wtowt þat wisdome mak devorss
Thay rin lyk wyld vndantit horss
but brydillis to and fro
Thair curage sa ourcu[m]is thair corss
Thrwt heit of blude it hes sic forss
Bot gif þe mynd haif sum remorss
of god all is ago
This wid fantastyk (n, struck through) lust but lufe
dois so ȝung me[n] to madness mvfe
That thay ma nowthir rest nor rufe
Till thay mischeif þair sellis
haif thay thair harlottis in behufe
Thay sussy not thair god abufe
Thair fame thair wirschep nor reprufe
off honor nor ocht ellis
ferme luve wt prudens suld be vsit
Thot sum allegeand to excusit
Saying þat luve wt witt inclusit
ȝit is not worth a buttoun
Sic vane opinioun is confusit
That ma[n] but ressoun may be rusit
Quha bene wt beistly lust abusit
I hald him bot ane muttoun
Quha wald in luve be estimat
Suld haif þair hairtis ay Elevat
wt m[er]ciall (deidis, struck through) myndis in doing þat
mycht causs thair fais to dowt thame
Thocht wemen self be temerat
Thay luve no man effeminat
and haldis thame bot I wat not quhat
That ca[n] noth be wtowt thame
ȝit ma[n] suld fauour thame howbeid
Thay be bot necessar of neid
Becauss we cum of thame in deid
Thair personis suld be (pr, struck through) prysit
As grund is ordand to beir seid
So is the woman born to breid
The fruct of ma[n] and þat to feid
as nature hes dewysit
Schort to conclude I wald bath knew
That Luvaris suld be leill and trew
and ladeis suld all thingis eschew
That ma thair honor smot
Be p[er]manent þat wald p[er]sew
and rin not reklesly to rew
not as I direct adew
Thuss I depairt q Scott
Ffinis
Author: Scott

div.head: Heir endis the prayiss of weme[n] And followis the contempt of Blyndit luve [etc]

head.title: Quha will behald of lufe the chance

lg.l: Quha will behald of lufe the chance
wt sueit dissauyng countenance
in quhais fair dissimvlance
lg.note: (Curved line beside last three lines, [may none assure] beside line)
lg.l: Quhilk is begun with inconstance
and endis not but variance
Scho haldis wt continwance
lg.note: (Curved line beside last three lines, [no seruiture] beside line)

lg.l: Discretioun and considerance
ar both out of hir gouirnance
quhairfoir of it ([with] struck through, [the] above) ([long] struck through, [schort] above) plesance
lg.note: (Curved line beside last three lines, [may not indure] beside line)
lg.l: Scho is so new of acquentance
The auld gais fra remembrance
Thus I gife our the obseruanss
lg.note: (Curved line beside last three lines, [of luvis cure] beside line)

lg.l: It is ane pount of ignorance
To lufe in sic distemperance
Sen tyme mispendit may avance
lg.note: (Curved line beside last three lines, [no creature] beside line)
lg.l: In luve to keip allegance
it war als nyss an ordinance
as quha wald bid ane deid man dance
lg.note: (Curved line beside last three lines, [In sepulture] beside line)

lg.l: Ffinis q dumbar

head.title: Leif luve my luve no langar thow it lyk

lg.l: Leif luve my luve no langar thow it lyk
alter ȝour amouris into obserwans
Eschew the swerd of wengeance or it stryk
ȝour lust and plesance turne in repentans
off misdeid me[n]d of kissing mak conscienss
Go luve our god or nytbour and sathan oursett
Punyss weill the flesch for thyn awin offens
Haif e to god and brek the diuillis net
Woluptous lyfe quhy thinkis tho so sueit
Knawing the deth þat no ma[n] may ewaid
Syne perseveiris in flesly lust and heit
no sawis may the fro thy synnis p[er]suaid
Contempny[n]g god off not that the hes maid
tresting in to this brukle lyfe and vane
Repent in tyme devoyd the of this laid
and knaw in hell thair is Eternall pane
Ffinis
Author unknown

head.title: Quhat meneth this Quhat is this windir vre

lg.l: Quhat meneth this Quhat is this windir vre
of purveance gife I sall it call
of god of luve, þat fals thame so assure
and trew allace doun of þe quheill bene fall
and ȝit in suth this is þe worst of all
That falsheid wrangfully of trewt hes the name
and trewt agane of falsheid beiris the name
This blind chance this stormy avinture
In luve haith most his experience
for quho þat doith wt trewt most his cure
Sall for his meid fynd most offens
That serwith luve for all his diligens
Ffor quho can fayne vndir lawleheid
he falis not to fynd grace and speid
For I luvit one, full lang syne agone
wt all my hairt body and full mycht
and to be deid my hairt can not gone
frome his haist bot hald þat he heth hicht
Thot I be banischit out of hir sicht
and by hir mowth dampnit þat I suld dy
vnto my behest ȝit I will evir obey
Ffor evir saith þt the warld began
Quha sa list luke and in story reid
he sall ay find þat the trew man (^ with dot above) wes put abak qr as þe ( falsheid
yfurtherid wes, for luve takis none heid
To sley the trewt and haif of thame no chairge
Quhair as the fals gois frely at thair lairge
I tak record of palamydes
The trew ma[n] that noble worthy knyt
That evir luvit and of his pane no reles
notwtstanding his manheid and his mycht
Luve vnto him did full grit vnricht
for ay the mair he did in chevelry
The mair he wes hindred by invy
and ay the bettir he did in every place
Thruch his knychheid and bussy pane
The ferdir wes he frome his ladeis grace
Ffor to hir m[er]cy mycht he not attane
and fro his deth he cowd him not refrane
for no denger bot ay obey and serue
as he best cowd plane till he sterue
Quhat wes the fyne also of hercules
For all his conquess and his worthiness
That wes of strenth allone peirles
Ffor lyk as bukis of him list express
he sett pillaris thruch his he provess
away at gades for to signifye
That no ma[n] micht him pass in chevelry
The (unclear word, struck through) quhilk piller fer beȝond ind
Be sett of gold for a reme[m]brance
and for all that wes he set behind
wt thame that luve list febly awance
for him set last vpone a dance
aganis quhome help may not stryfe
for all his trewt he lost his lyfe
Phebus also for all his plesant licht
quhen þat he went heir in erth law
vnto þe hairt wt venus sicht
ywoundit wes thruch schot of cupeidis bow
and ȝit his lady list him not to knaw
Thot for hir luve his hairt suld bleid
Scho let him go and tuk of him none heid
Quhat sall I say of ȝung piramus
of trew tristram for all his he renoun
of achilles and antonius
of arceit or of him palamoun
Quhat wes the end of thair passioun
bot eftir sorrow dyis and tha[n] thair graif
Lo heir the guerdoun þat thais luvaris haif
Bot fals jasone wt his dowbilnes
þat wes vntrew at colkoss to medee
and theseus rute of vnkyndnes
and wt thais two eik the fals enee
Lo thus the fals ay in on degre
had in luve thair lust and all þair will
and saif falsheid þair wes none vþir skill
Off phebus eik the fals arceit
and demophone eik for his slewth
Thay had þair lust and all þair haill delyt
for all þair falsheid and grit vntrewth
Thus evir luve allace & þat is rewth
his fals luvaris furtherith quhat he may
and slayis the trew iniustly day by day
ffor trew adone was slane wt the bore
amyd the forrest in the grene schaid
for venus luve he felt all the soir
Bot vulcanus wt hir no m[er]cy maid
That fowll churle had mony nychtis glaid
quhair mars hir knyt and hir man
To fynd m[er]cy confort none he can
Also the ȝung fresche ypomedes
So lusty fre as of his (lynage, struck through) curage
That for to serf wt all his hairt he chess
athalans so fair of hir visage
Bot luve allace quyt him so his vage
wt crewall denger planely at þe last
That wt the deth guerdounles he past
Lo heir the fyne of luvis seruice
Lo how þat lufe can his serwantis quyte
Lo how he can his faithfull men dispyss
To sla the trew me[n] and fals to respyte
Lo how he dois the swerd of sorrow byte
In hairtis suche as most his lustis obey
To saif the fals and do the trew to dey
Ffor faith nor aith word nor assurance
Trew meny[n]g await or business
Still port nor fathfull attendance
manheid nor mycht in armes worthiness
p[er]sute of wirschip nor he provess
In strange landis ryding nor travell
full littill or nocht in luve dois awaill
Perrell of deth nowdir in se nor land
hungir nor thrist sorrow nor seikness
nor grit int[er]prysis for to tak on hand
Schedding of blude na ma[n]full hardiness
nor oft wounding at sautis by distress
Nor in pairting of deth nor lyfe also
all is for not luve takith no heid þairto
Bot lesingis wt hir flattry
Thruch hir falsheid and wt hir dowbilness
wt tailis new and mony fanyd le
By fals semblant and counterfit humbleness
vndir cullour depaynt wt steidfastness
wt fraud coverid vndir a peteouss face
accept[it] be now rathest vnto grace
And can him self now best magnifie
wt faynid port and presumptioun
Thay haunt thair causs wt fals surquedry
vndir menyng of dowlle intentioun
To think on thing in thair opinioun
and say a nowthir to sett him self aloft
and hindir trewt as it is sene full oft
O god of luve wt thy blind variance
yment wt chenge and grit vnstabilness
now vp now doun so rynny[n]g is thy chance
That the to trust may be no sickerness
I (partial word starting with w, struck through) knaw the nothing bot for dubilness
And quho þat is an archeir and is blend
markith no thing bot schutith by wend
And for þat he hes no discretioun
wtout adwyse he lettis his arrowis go
Ffor lak of sicht and also of ressoun
In his schoting it hapnis oft so
To hurt his frend rathir tha[n] his fo
So dois this god wt his scherp flone
The trew he slais and lattis the fals gone
q chauser

head.title: The merle and the nycthtingall

lg.l: In may as that aurora did vpspring
wt cristall ene chasing þe cluddis sable
I hard a merle wt mirry notis sing
a sang of lufe wt voce ryt co[m]fortable
agane the orient bemis amiable
vpone a blisfull brenche of lawry grene
This wes hir sentens sueit and delectable
a lusty lyfe in luves seruice bene
Vndir this brench ra[n] doun a revir bricht
of balmy liquor cristallyne of hew
agane the hevinly aisur skyis licht
Quhair did vpone þe toþ[er] syd p[er]sew
a nychtingall wt suggurit notis new
quhois angell fedderis as the pacok schone
This wes hir song and of a sentens trew
all luve is lost bot vpone god allone
With notis glaid and glorious armony
This joyfull merle so salust scho the day
quhill rong the widdis of hir melody
Saying awalk ȝe luvaris o this may
Lo fresche flora hes flurest every spray
as natur hes hir taucht þe noble quene
The feild bene clothit in a (noble, struck through) new array
a lusty lyfe in luvis seruice bene
Nevir suetar noys wes hard wt levand ma[n]
na maid this mirry gentill nychtingaill
Hir sound went wt the rever as it ran
outthrow the fresche and flureist lusty vaill
o merle q scho o fule stynt of thy taill
Ffor in thy song gud sentens is þair none
for boith is tynt the tyme and the travaill
of every luve bot vpone god allone
Seiss q the merle thy preching nychtingale
Sall folk thair ȝewth spend in to holiness
of ȝung sanctis growis auld feyndis but fable
Ffy ypocreit in ȝeiris tendirness
agane the law of kynd thow gois express
That crukit aige makis on wt ȝewth serene
Quhome natur of co[n]ditionis maid dyverss
a lusty lyfe in luves seruice bene
The nychtingaill said fule reme[m]bir the
That both in ȝewth and eild and every hour
The luve of god most deir to ma[n] suld be
That him of nocht wrocht lyk his awin figour
and deit him self fro deid him to succour
o quhithir wes kythit þair trew lufe or none
he is most trew & steidfast paramour
all luve is lost bot vpone him allone
The merle said quhy put god so grit bewte
In ladeis wt sic woma[n]ly having
Bot gife he wald þat thay suld luvit be
To (eik, struck through) luve eik natur gaif thame inclynny[n]g
and he of natur þat wirker wes and king
wald no thing frustir put nor lat be sene
In to his creature of his awin making
a lusty lyfe in luves seruice bene
The nychtingall said nocht to þat behufe
put god sic bewty in a ladeis face
That scho suld haif the tha[n]k þ[er]foir or lufe
